Abstract

We prove Helly-type theorems for line transversals to disjoint unit balls inÂ â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In particular, we show that a family of nâ©¾2â¢dğ‘›2ğ‘‘n\geqslant 2ditalic_n â©¾ 2 italic_d disjoint unit balls in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has a line transversal if, for some ordering â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º of the balls, any subfamily of 2â¢d2ğ‘‘2d2 italic_d balls admits a line transversal consistent with â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º. 1 Introduction

Hellyâ€™s celebrated theorem, published in 1923, states that a finite family of convex sets in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has non-empty intersection if and only if any subfamily of size at most d+1ğ‘‘1d+1italic_d + 1 has non-empty intersection. Subsequent results of similar flavor (that is, if every subset of size kğ‘˜kitalic_k of a set ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S has property ğ’«ğ’«\cal Pcaligraphic_P then ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S has property ğ’«ğ’«\cal Pcaligraphic_P) have been called Helly-type theorems and the minimal such kğ‘˜kitalic_k is known as the associated Helly number. Helly-type theorems and tight bounds on Helly numbers have been the object of active research in combinatorial geometry. In this paper, we investigate Helly-type theorems for the existence of line transversals to a family of objects, i.e. lines that intersect every member of the family.

History.

The earliest Helly-type theorems in geometric transversal theory appeared about five decades ago. In 1957, HadwigerÂ [12] showed that an ordered family ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S of compact convex sets in the plane admits a line transversal if every triple admits a line transversal compatible with the ordering. (Note that a line transversal to ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S may not respect the ordering on ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S; to prove the existence of a line transversal that respects the ordering onÂ ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S one needs the assumption that any four-tuple admits an order-respecting line transversal.) In what follows, we shall talk about a Hadwiger-type theorem when the family of objects under consideration is ordered.

The same year, DanzerÂ [5] proved the following result concerning families of pairwise disjoint unit discs in the plane: if such a family consists of at least 5 discs, and if any 5 of these discs are met by some line, then there exists a line meeting all the discs of the family. This answered a question of HadwigerÂ [11], who gave an example (5 circles, almost touching and with centers forming a regular pentagon) which shows thatÂ 5 cannot be replaced byÂ 4. GrÃ¼nbaumÂ [8] showed that the same result holds if â€œunit discâ€ is replaced by â€œunit squareâ€, and conjectured that the result holds for families of disjoint translates of any compact convex set in the plane. This long-standing conjecture was finally proved by TverbergÂ [19]. A weaker form of the conjecture which assumed 128 instead of 5 had been established earlier by KatchalskiÂ [16].

DanzerÂ [5] conjectured that Helly-type theorems exist for line transversals to disjoint unit balls in arbitrary dimension. The first positive result was obtained by HadwigerÂ [10] for the case of families of â€œthinly distributedâ€ balls, where the distance between any two balls is at least the sum of their radii. This result was extended by Ambrus et al.Â [1] to disjoint unit balls, in arbitrary dimension, the centers of which are at distance at least 2â¢2+22222\sqrt{2+\sqrt{2}}2 square-root start_ARG 2 + square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG. Danzerâ€™s conjecture for three-dimensional disjoint unit balls, without additional assumption on their distribution, was only settled in 2001 by Holmsen et al.Â [14]. It should be stressed that in dimension three (and higher), neither Hadwiger nor Helly-type theorems exist for line transversals to general convex objects, not even for translates of a convex compact setÂ [15].

In his paperÂ [5], Danzer also asked whether the Helly number for line transversals to disjoint unit balls in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a strictly increasing function of dğ‘‘ditalic_d. The only known lower bound is the planar example of HadwigerÂ [11]. This number was proved to be at most d2superscriptğ‘‘2d^{2}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for thinly distributed balls in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by HadwigerÂ [10], a bound improved toÂ 2â¢dâˆ’12ğ‘‘12d-12 italic_d - 1 by GrÃ¼nbaumÂ [9] using the topological Helly theorem. For disjoint unit balls in dimension three, Holmsen et al.Â [14] proved bounds of respectivelyÂ 12121212 andÂ 46464646 for the Hadwiger-type and Helly-type theorems, which were later improved toÂ 12121212 andÂ 18181818 by Cheong et al.Â [4].

We refer the reader to the recent survey by WengerÂ [20] for a broader discussion of geometric transversal theory.

Our results.

In this paper we complete the proof of Danzerâ€™s conjecture. More precisely, we show that Helly-type theorems exist for line transversals to families of pairwise-inflatable balls in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Pairwise-inflatable families of balls are not only more general than families of disjoint congruent balls but allow to generalize most of our proofs obtained in three or four dimensions to arbitrary dimension; the key property, which we prove in this paper, is that the set of pairwise-inflatable families is closed under intersection with affine subspaces, unlike the set of families of disjoint congruent balls.

An order-respecting line transversal to a subset of an ordered family is a line transversal that respects the order induced by the family on that subset. An ordered family â„±â„±\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F of pairwise-inflatable balls is said to have property (Oâ¢R)â¢Tğ‘‚ğ‘…ğ‘‡(OR)T( italic_O italic_R ) italic_T if it admits a (order-respecting) line transversal. Our first main result requires that the line transversals to the subfamilies induce consistent orderings:

Theorem 1.

We then remove the condition on the ordering at the cost of increasing the Helly number toÂ 4â¢dâˆ’14ğ‘‘14d-14 italic_d - 1 and restricting ourselves to disjoint unit balls:

Theorem 2.

For any family of disjoint unit balls in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Tâ¢(4â¢dâˆ’1)ğ‘‡4ğ‘‘1T(4d-1)italic_T ( 4 italic_d - 1 ) implies Tğ‘‡Titalic_T.

Our results are thus both qualitative and quantitative: we generalize Danzerâ€™s result to arbitrary dimension and prove that the Helly number grows at most linearly with the dimension. We build on the work of Holmsen et al.Â [14] who obtained results similar to TheoremsÂ 1 andÂ 2 for disjoint unit balls in three dimensions, albeit with larger bounds on Helly numbers (12121212 and 46464646 instead of 6666 and 11111111, respectively). A previous version of this paper, also restricted to disjoint unit balls in three dimensions, appeared in the Symposium on Computational GeometryÂ 2005Â [3].

Paper outline.

To prove TheoremÂ 1, we start with a family of balls having property Oâ¢Râ¢Tâ¢(2â¢d)ğ‘‚ğ‘…ğ‘‡2ğ‘‘ORT(2d)italic_O italic_R italic_T ( 2 italic_d ) and continuously shrink them until that property no longer holds, following Hadwigerâ€™s approachÂ [12]. Before the set of order-respecting line transversals to a 2â¢d2ğ‘‘2d2 italic_d-tuple of balls disappears, it first reduces to a single line (CorollaryÂ 12) and this line is an isolated line transversal to 2â¢dâˆ’12ğ‘‘12d-12 italic_d - 1 of the balls (PropositionÂ 13). That line has then to be a line transversal to the whole family and TheoremÂ 1 follows; considerations on geometric permutations yield TheoremÂ 2.

Proving the two properties mentioned above (CorollaryÂ 12 and PropositionÂ 13) is elementary in the plane but requires considerably more work in higher dimension. Our proofs rely on PropositionÂ 4, the cornerstone of this paper, which shows that the directions of order-respecting line transversals to a family of pairwise-inflatable balls form a strictly convex subset of ğ•Šdâˆ’1superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘1\mathbb{S}^{d-1}blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This directly implies CorollaryÂ 12 and yields that order-respecting line transversals form a contractible set in line space. From there, a well-known topological analogue of Hellyâ€™s theorem (TheoremÂ 3) leads to a weaker version of TheoremÂ 1 sufficient to prove PropositionÂ 13.

Two topological spaces A,Bğ´ğµA,Bitalic_A , italic_B are homotopy equivalent if there exists a third space Cğ¶Citalic_C such that both Ağ´Aitalic_A and BğµBitalic_B are deformation retracts ofÂ Cğ¶Citalic_C. A space that is homotopy equivalent to a single point is said to be contractible. A homology cell is a non-empty set with trivial homology, e.g. a point. 3 The cone of directions is strictly convex

Lemma 10.

If â„±â„±\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F is a sequence of pairwise inflatable balls in â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT then ğ’¦â¢(â„±)ğ’¦â„±\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) is strictly convex.

Proof.

We already know that ğ’¦â¢(â„±)ğ’¦â„±\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) is convex. If ğ’¦â¢(â„±)ğ’¦â„±\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) is not strictly convex then it has to contain on its boundary a great circle arc. By the previous lemma, if vâˆˆâˆ‚ğ’¦â¢(â„±)ğ‘£ğ’¦â„±v\in\partial\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})italic_v âˆˆ âˆ‚ caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) then Pvâ¢(â„±)subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘£â„±P_{v}(\mathcal{F})italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_F ) is a point. This implies, by Hellyâ€™s theorem, that the boundary of ğ’¦â¢(â„±)ğ’¦â„±\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) consists of (finitely many) curve arcs that are either (a) directions of bitangent lines lying in bitangent planes or (b) directions of tritangent lines. The directions of bitangent lines lying in bitangent planes to two balls contain a great circle arc only if the two balls are tangent, which cannot occur in our situation.

Therefore, if ğ’¦â¢(â„±)ğ’¦â„±\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) is not strictly convex then it contains in its boundary a great circle arc of directions of lines tangent to three balls. These directions, being on a great circle arc, are parallel to a given plane. In projective geometry, parallels to a plane are recast as lines intersecting the â€œline at infinityâ€ of that plane. Thus, if ğ’¦â¢(â„±)ğ’¦â„±\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) is not strictly convex, â„±â„±\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F contains three balls with infinitely many common tangents that intersect a fixed line at infinity. Such configurations were tabulated by Megyesi and SottileÂ [18]. Their cases (i), (iii), and (iv) cannot arise with disjoint spheres and the fixed line at infinity. The remaining possibility (case (ii)) is that the three spheres are tangent to a cone whose apex lies on the fixed line. In our case, that line is at infinity so this cone is a cylinder and the spheres have equal radii and aligned centers; all common tangents then have the same direction and cannot form a great circle arc. âˆ

We will need the generalization of LemmaÂ 9 to arbitrary dimension.

6 Conclusion and open problems

We conclude this paper with a few comments on our results followed by open problems they suggest.

  • â€¢

    Weaker versions of TheoremsÂ 1 andÂ 2 (with constants quadratic in dğ‘‘ditalic_d) can be obtained more easily, using only LemmaÂ 4 and the reasoning of Holmsen et al.Â [14].

  • â€¢

    In the plane, if three disjoint convex sets {C1,â€¦,C3}subscriptğ¶1â€¦subscriptğ¶3\{C_{1},\ldots,C_{3}\}{ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } pin a line â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ then they are all tangent to â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ and alternate: the first and the third are on the same side of â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“, the second is on the other side. Thus, if â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ does not intersect a fourth convex set C4subscriptğ¶4C_{4}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT some triple {Cx,Cy,C4}subscriptğ¶ğ‘¥subscriptğ¶ğ‘¦subscriptğ¶4\{C_{x},C_{y},C_{4}\}{ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } has no line transversal at all. This explains why, in Hadwigerâ€™s original proof the â€œHadwiger numberâ€ is the same as the pinning number. A way to reduce the bound in TheoremÂ 1 toÂ 2â¢dâˆ’12ğ‘‘12d-12 italic_d - 1 could be to prove a similar statement: given a sequence of pairwise inflatable balls â„±â„±\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F that pins a line â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ and a ball Cğ¶Citalic_C not intersecting â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“, there is a subsequence â„±â€²âŠ‚â„±superscriptâ„±â€²â„±\mathcal{F}^{\prime}\subset\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ‚ caligraphic_F of size |â„±|âˆ’1â„±1|\mathcal{F}|-1| caligraphic_F | - 1 such that â„±â€²âˆª{C}superscriptâ„±â€²ğ¶\mathcal{F}^{\prime}\cup\{C\}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆª { italic_C } has no transversal respecting the ordering on â„±â€²superscriptâ„±â€²\mathcal{F}^{\prime}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We have no idea whether such a statement actually holds.

  • â€¢

    To apply the Topological Helly Theorem, we did not actually need that ğ’¦â¢(â„±)ğ’¦â„±\mathcal{K}(\mathcal{F})caligraphic_K ( caligraphic_F ) is convex, only that it is contractible. This may be important for further generalization.

  • â€¢

    For general convex sets, even smooth ones, the pinning number is at least 6666 as the following example using six unit-radius cylinders in â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, due to GÃ¼nter Rote, shows: the first three cylinders are parallel to the xğ‘¥xitalic_x-axis and their axes go through the points (0,1,0)010(0,1,0)( 0 , 1 , 0 ), (0,âˆ’1,1)011(0,-1,1)( 0 , - 1 , 1 ) and (0,1,2)012(0,1,2)( 0 , 1 , 2 ) respectively. The last three cylinders are parallel to the yğ‘¦yitalic_y-axis and their axes go through the points (1,0,10)1010(1,0,10)( 1 , 0 , 10 ), (âˆ’1,0,11)1011(-1,0,11)( - 1 , 0 , 11 ) and (1,0,12)1012(1,0,12)( 1 , 0 , 12 ) respectively. The six cylinders have only one transversalâ€”the zğ‘§zitalic_z-axisâ€”but any five have an infinite number of transversals.

  • â€¢

    LemmasÂ 5 andÂ 6 imply that two disjoint balls A,BâŠ‚â„dğ´ğµsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘A,B\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_A , italic_B âŠ‚ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are pairwise-inflatable if and only if they can be expressed as sections of two disjoint congruent balls in some higher-dimensional space. Generalizing this, let us call a set â„±â„±\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F of balls in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT inflatable if â„±â„±\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F can be expressed as the intersection of a higher-dimensional set of disjoint congruent balls with a dğ‘‘ditalic_d-dimensional affine subspace. Batog recently showed that it is NP-hard to decide whether a given collection of balls is inflatableÂ [2].


Problem 1.

What is the maximum number of geometric permutations of pairwise-inflatable balls in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT?

To generalize TheoremÂ 2 to pairwise-inflatable balls, one would need to extend TheoremÂ 16 to those families. It is known that the number of geometric permutations of nğ‘›nitalic_n disjoint balls in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is at most 3333 if the balls have equal radii and Î˜â¢(ndâˆ’1)Î˜superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘1\Theta(n^{d-1})roman_Î˜ ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) if the ratio

largest radiussmallest radiuslargest radiussmallest radius\frac{\hbox{largest radius}}{\hbox{smallest radius}}divide start_ARG largest radius end_ARG start_ARG smallest radius end_ARG

is not bounded independently of nğ‘›nitalic_nÂ [21].

Problem 2.

For which classes of objects is the cone of directions ğ’¦â¢(A1,â€¦,An)ğ’¦subscriptğ´1normal-â€¦subscriptğ´ğ‘›\mathcal{K}(A_{1},\ldots,A_{n})caligraphic_K ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) convex, or at least contractible?

Our proof of convexity for the cone of directions of balls collapses for balls that are not pairwise-inflatable. In fact, the set QAâ¢BFsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ´ğµğ¹Q_{AB}^{F}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not necessarily convex if BğµBitalic_B is much smaller than Ağ´Aitalic_A but very close to it.

Problem 3.

For which classes of objects is the set of order-respecting line transversals always connected?

Our proof of TheoremÂ 1 follows from (i) a bounded pinning number and (ii) the fact that as the set of order-respecting line transversals to a sequence disappears it first reduces to a single line. For strictly convex objects, property (ii) follows from the connectivity of the set of order-respecting transversals. Surprisingly, it is an open question whether this set is connected for even 4444 disjoint balls in â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, whereas it is known to be connected for any triple of disjoint convex objectsÂ [7, Lemma 74]. We conjecture that general convex sets in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have a bounded pinning number. Thus, understanding how general this connectivity property is would provide insight in how general the example of Holmsen and MatousekÂ [15], convex sets whose translates do not admit a Hadwiger theorem, actually is. Of course, a positive answer to ProblemÂ 2 for a particular family of convex sets implies a positive answer to ProblemÂ 3 for that family as well.

Problem 4.

Given a collection of disjoint unit balls, assume that any subset of size 2â¢dâˆ’12ğ‘‘12d-12 italic_d - 1 admits a line transversal. Does any subset of size 2â¢dâˆ’12ğ‘‘12d-12 italic_d - 1 admit a compatible line transversal?

In other words, can our â€œweak Hadwiger theoremâ€ (LemmaÂ 15) be strengthened into a Hadwiger theorem with a better constant than TheoremÂ 1?

Problem 5.

Is the pinning number of disjoint unit balls in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT equal to 2â¢dâˆ’12ğ‘‘12d-12 italic_d - 1?

Surprisingly, the only known lower bound on the Helly number is the construction done by Hadwiger fifty years ago. Note that the bound in our Hadwiger theorem has to be higher than the pinning number of the corresponding family and one can therefore look for a lower bound on the pinning number. Intuitively, considerations on the dimension suggest that the pinning number in dimension dğ‘‘ditalic_d cannot be less thanÂ 2â¢dâˆ’12ğ‘‘12d-12 italic_d - 1, the dimension of the underlying line space beingÂ 2â¢dâˆ’22ğ‘‘22d-22 italic_d - 2.
